Dear Ms. Sears:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced facility completed on
12/27/2022. An Exit Conference was held with you on 1/9/2023. Due to the violations, a
written corrective action plan is required. It should be noted that violations of any licensing
statutes rules and are also violations of the MISEP and your contract. The corrective
action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the following:
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MISEP citation.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• An explanation why previous corrective action plans have not
obtained and maintained compliance for rules found in repeat
noncompliance.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, a regular license will be issued. If
you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action will result.
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, a six-month provisional will be
matter.
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at 734-395-0920.
Sincerely,
Lonia Perry Calloway, Licensing Consultant

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except
for the following:
Rule 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(5) Within 15 days of the conclusion of the evaluation, an
agency shall complete a written report that includes all of
the following information:
(d) Dates and places of contacts, names of persons
interviewed, and names of the interviewers. If children
are interviewed, their last names shall not be included in
the report.
Two of six special evaluations reviewed did not clearly and
consistently document the date or place of contact where
all persons were interviewed.
Rule 400.12413 Medical and dental policy.
(1) An agency's medical and dental care policy shall, at a
minimum, include all of the following:
(c) A physical examination for each child as follows,
unless a greater frequency is medically indicated:
(ii) For a child 2 years of age or older, a physical
examination shall have been completed within 12
months before placement or a new physical examination
shall be completed within 30 calendar days after
placement.
Two of eight open foster child records reviewed did not
show compliance:
• One child's medical examination was due by
5/30/2022 and was completed 25 days late on
6/24/2022.
• A second child's medical examination was due by
6/30/2022 and was completed 13 days late on
7/13/2022.
Rule 400.12413 Medical and dental policy.

(1) An agency's medical and dental care policy shall, at a
minimum, include all of the following:
(f) The provision of a dental examination and any
treatment required for each child who is 4 years of age
and older, including both of the following:
(i) A dental examination within 12 months before
placement or a new dental examination shall be
completed not more than 90 calendar days after
placement.
Three of eight open foster child records reviewed did not
show compliance:
• One child's dental was due by 5/1/2022 and was
completed 115 days late on 8/24/22.
• A second child's dental was due by 7/30/2022 and
was completed 21 days late on 8/20/2022.
• A third child's dental was due by 8/29/2022 and
was completed 21 days late on 9/19/2022.
Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for
each child and parent or parents, as follows:
(a) Within 30 calendar days from removal from the home.
One of five initial service plans (ISP) reviewed was five
days late.
Repeat Violation- Interim March 2022
Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for
each child and parent or parents, as follows:
(b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial removal and
at least once every 90 calendar days thereafter.
One of 15 updated service plans (USP) reviewed was
completed six days late.
Repeat Violation- Interim March 2022.
Rule 400.12419 Initial service plans.

(1) The initial service plan, as required in R
400.12418(2)(a), shall include all of the following
information:
(c) Assessment of the placement selection criteria as
required under R 400.12404 (4).
Two of five ISPs reviewed did not show documentation of
(c) as required by the rule.
Repeat Violation- Interim March 2022.
Rule 400.12502 Program statement.
(2) An agency shall give a copy of the program statement
to a youth before placement in independent living.
One of three open independent living youth records
reviewed did not show compliance as required by the rule.
Repeat Violation-Interim March 2022
Rule 400.12503 Policies and procedures.
(3) An agency shall provide a youth in independent living
with a copy of the agency’s policies and procedures
required by this rule.
One of three open independent living youth records
reviewed did not show compliance as required by the rule.
Repeat Violation-Interim March 2022.
Rule 400.12509 Independent living record.
(3) The case record shall contain all of the following
information and documentation, which shall be recorded
within 30 calendar days after placement in independent
and updated at least once every 90 calendar days:
(o)
Three of seven independent living USPs reviewed (related
to one of three youth records) were one, one, and four
days late respectively.
Rule 400.12607 Agency recommendation.

(4) An agency shall provide the applicant with a signed
and dated copy of the evaluation and recommendation
upon its completion.
Two of four adoptive family records reviewed did not show
compliance as required by the rule. The respective
evaluations were provided one month and almost three
months after the respective 2/7/2022 and 9/9/2022
evaluation's completion/approval date.
Repeat Violation- Interim March 2022.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an MISEP violation. Please note that there are
additional MISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1. The facility is in
compliance will all additional MISEP requirements except for the following:
MISEP 4.22 Child Welfare Information System (Commitment
22).
DHHS will maintain an operational statewide
automated child welfare information system which will
be the primary tracking system and satisfy federal
reporting requirements
Various open and closed foster child and independent
living records as well as adoption records reviewed did not
show consistent MISACWIS uploads of all required
documents (i.e., signed service plans, treatment plans,
DHS-1105, DHS-69s, medical passports, and or other
documents), at the time of review. Proof of the documents
were provided prior to exit.
MISEP 6.19(c) Assessments and Service Plans, Content
(Commitment 69).
Service plans shall be signed by the caseworker, the
caseworker's supervisor, the parent(s}, and the
child(ren), if of age to participate. If the parent(s) or
child(ren) or both are not available or decline to sign the
plan, the service plan shall include an explanation of the
steps taken to involve them and shall identify any follow-
up actions to be taken to secure their participation in
services.

One of eight open foster child records and one of three
open independent living records reviewed did not show
compliance:
• The foster child’s 1/31/2022-3/1/2022 ISP
treatment plan was not signed by the birth parent.
• The independent living youth’s 4/1/2022-
6/27/2022 and 6/28/2022-9/22/2022 respective
USP was not signed by the youth.
Repeat Violation- Interim March 2022.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a MDHHS Contract violation. Please note that
there are additional MDHHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be included in
section 1. The facility is in compliance will all additional MDHHS Contract/Policy
requirements except for the following:
FOM 722-8 Case Service Plans- Overview, Types, And
Timeframes.
Supervisor Approval:
The supervisor must approve all case service plans
within 14 days of the end of the report period.
Five of 20 open foster child services plans (related to five
of eight child records) and six of seven independent youth
service plans (related to three of three youth records)
reviewed were approved late:

• A second child’s 6/21/2022-9/13/2022 USP was

• A third child’s 6/3/2022-8/19/2022 USP was
approved six days late on 9/8/2022. This child’s
8/20/2022-11/17/2022 USP was approved five
days late on 12/6/2022.
Independent youth records:
• One youth’s 3/19/2022-6/16/2022 USP was
approved seven days late on 7/7/2022. The youth’s
6/17/2022-9/14/2022 USP was approved five days
late on 10/3/2022.

• A second youth’s 4/1/2022-6/27/2022 USP was
approved 14 days late on 7/25/2022. This youth’s
6/28/2022-9/22/2022 USP was approved 13 days
late on 10/19/2022.
• A third youth’s 2/2/2022-5/2/2022 USP was
approved seven days late on 5/24/2022. This
youth’s 8/1/2022-10/29/2022 USP was approved
10 days late on 11/23/2022.
Repeat Violation- Interim March 2022.
FOM 722-8D Treatment plans.
Agreement and Signature:
Once completed and approved, the caseworker must
obtain signatures from the following individuals, as
applicable:
• Foster parents, relative caregivers, and unrelated
court ordered caregivers.
The caseworker must obtain signatures from all
applicable individuals and upload the signatures pages
into the electronic case record within 30 days of the
report date.
One of 20 foster child treatment plans was not signed by
the caregiver.
Repeat Violation – Interim March 2022.
FOM 722-8E Foster Care/Juvenile Justice Action Summary.
The caseworker must complete the DHS-69, Foster
Care/Juvenile Justice Action Summary, and upload to
MiSACWIS within the timeframe required for the
specified change.
• Three days prior to a planned placement change,
or within three business days of an emergency
placement change
One of eight open foster child records reviewed did not
show documentation of a DHS-69 related to a 4/14/2022
and 4/18/2022 placement change for the child.
Repeat Violation- Interim March 2022.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:

R400.12327(6)(b): Special evaluation
The agency was apprised that it shall consistently and clearly show documentation
that the foster parent was advised of their rights to write a written response to the
special evaluation.
722-8 D Treatment Plans
The agency was apprised treatment plans shall consistently be dated, inclusive of a
notation of the birth parent ‘s or caregiver’s refusals to sign.

VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD

licensing period.
AND

Progress was made by the agency on its corrective actions plans:
The agency made significant progress with its Interim inspection corrective action
plan, as denoted by the decrease in noncompliance's. Notwithstanding that the
agency was not totally successful with all areas of the corrective action plan as
indicated by the repeat violations in this Renewal Inspection report.
The agency provided documentation of various internal corrective action plan steps
taken to achieve its plan. This was inclusive of sample service plan development
tools, noted policy reviews, tracking tools, trainings and meeting
agendas/discussions, and samples of monthly supervision with staff, all showing
efforts to succeed on this corrective action plan.
The agency's second corrective action plan related to Special Investigation
2022C0420019 for a complaint received 5/20/2022. The allegation was that the
agency had not submitted five closed adoption records to the Department of Health
and Human Services(DHHS) for permanent retention one year after finalization of
the adoptions. The agency was found in violation of R400.12713(5) for Adoption
Placement Record. The agency submitted an acceptable corrective action plan on
7/19/2022, that indicated the five closed adoption records were all submitted to the
department by 6/10/2022. Receipt acknowledgement tracking forms were
previously provided showing those submissions. The agency’s corrective plan also
indicated the agency would keep a spreadsheet of closed adoption records that it
would review the third Tuesday of each month to track when closed adoption
records needed to be submitted to the department. The agency provided a copy of a
spreadsheet and proof of submissions by way of closed file tracker receipt
acknowledgement forms showing submission of closed adoption records to various
DHHS counties in June, July, August, September, and October of 2022. This
corrective plan has been completed.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrator’s report dated 12/8/2022 was received and reviewed. The
agency assessed its areas of noncompliance as indicated in the March 2022 Interim
Inspection report; and completed all other aspects as required by that document.
Interviews
The chief administrator, and licensing director/supervisor participated in the
12/13/2022 entrance conference. The entrance conference centered on a review
and discussion related to the last inspection’s corrective action plan, new staff, and
the agency’s current challenges if any, and status/program functioning. The
Department of Child Welfare Licensing (DCWL) Analyst attended the entrance

conference and presented her findings from the unlicensed relatives and foster
home visits.
The chief administrator, and licensing director/supervisor and three agency
supervisors participated in the 1/9/2023 exit conference. The exit conference
focused on a summary of staff interviews, and the results of the inspection/ indicated
rule and policy violations. Two foster care workers, one foster care/ adoption
worker, a licensing worker, an independent living youth worker, foster care/adoption
supervisor, two adoptive parents, and two independent living youths were
interviewed during this inspection.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS:
Two safety alerts were received this inspection from the DCWL Analyst:
Safety Alert # 1:
Concern:
On 11/9/2022 there were not working smoke detectors in the unlicensed relative’s
home. Please ensure there are working smoke detectors on all floors.
Resolution:
The agency reported the relative’s smoke alarms are now in working order. The
relative replaced all the batteries, which the agency confirmed via video
communication with the relative on 11/11/2022 at 10:00am.
Safety Alert #2:
Concern:
Please ensure there are working smoke detectors in the home. The smoke
detectors were beeping during the 11/2/2022 home visit.
Resolution:
The agency reported the relative’s smoke alarms are now in working order. The
relative replaced all the batteries, which the agency confirmed via video
communication with the relative.
Concern:
Window screens in the living room and dining room are torn/missing.
Resolution:
The agency reported the relative’s apartment complex ordered window screens to
replace the torn/missing screens; and all screens were replaced on 12/8/2022. The
agency verified this and provided pictures showing the window screen replacements.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules and/or MISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon
receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility will
be issued a renewal of their regular license.
